Might contain light spoilers !!!
So, this review is for Beatless and its sequel Beatless final stage. I see them as one, so I write one review.
Before review and my opinion about it I have to say one thing, this anime isn’t that regular anime which you watch it has a lot of dialogue and sometime can be confusing. A lot of events which happens in first half may look stupid and unexplained. But in second half you get almost all answers.  So, what I mean you can’t just use 3 episode or any other rule here, because most of the time after 3 episodesyou are going to be confuse.\n
Now about anime itself.  This anime tries to explain a lot of thing it and is your decision if it answered your questions or not. The topics I would say very interesting starting from social engineering and finishing can robots have feelings. These topics might look they not belong for this time, but they are. I could write an example, but then I have to spoil the plot, so I won’t do it in order to keep this review spoiler free.  So, if you have any interest in technologies, engineering or you are the guy who likes dystopia world you should watch it. If you a person who looks for fighting between beautiful robots I recommend skip it, I don’t say it this anime don’t have it but watching just for that won’t be entertaining and would be waste of time.\n
About story I really don’t want to spoil a lot most what you need is in the synopsis, but I would like to add it. There is 5 hIE, made by Super AI Hinggins, with 5 different visions about a future. Kouka is future without any robots, Snowdrop future without humans, Saturn future as it is now, Methode future where humans use tools more efficient and Lacia where humans co-exist with machines. And each of them tries to make a future base on their own vision. \n
I could talk about characters, but I don’t see a point because each of as has their own opinion about them and review would be too long. I can say one thing try to imagine you are in their position what you do in that situation and then you see that their decisions don’t look that stupid.\n
Music is very good. That electronic music makes this anime even more enjoyable. \n
Animation. What I can say it is a little to cheap for these days and could be done better. Personally, I would like that team behind GC would done animating instead of Diomedea.\n
Enjoyment. Probably if you reach this section you already know that I love it. Just a few last words, looking to other reviews you see a lot of negativity about this anime, but it shouldn’t be the cause why you shouldn’t try and at least see how future world looks after 4th industry revolution, because I think it is closet vision what will happen in upcoming 40-50 years.\n

This anime is so average. 

Pros:
1. Upbeat OP song by Garnidelia and great Ed theme from ClariS
2. The Sci-fi aspect of this series is very interesting
3. Soundtracks suit the anime very well and are also very unique
Cons:
1. Character designs are awfully boring. I mean just compare it to the novel, the anime stinks.
2. Generic characters with little to no backstories. Why?
3. No main plot after 8 episodes, srsly?
4. Nothing captivating happened for 8 episodes. Each issue is solved with plot convenience. 

This anime is so average. I first started watching this with the mindset of it being close to Plastic Memories or GuiltyCrown, but ohhhhh am I mistaken to a whole new level. This anime is so boring. Each episode I keep on hoping that a plot twist that I don't see coming will occur but no, every episode is plain and pointless.There's even a freakin' catwalk episode for no reason at all. I know if this is a Slice of Life anime then I won't care, but it isn't. It's a story focused anime. So, if its story didn't attract me, the heck should I even care. \n\n
The characters are the other worse part of the show. Each character is painfully generic. You can sum up their characteristic in only one word because that's how just much we learnt about them in the span of 8 episodes. No character development. No character drama. They are just there because the story needs them. Don't even get me started with their designs, so bad. I mean just compare it to the novel, the anime is just trash. I can already hear the disappointments from fellow Redjuice fans. Also, I don't usually complain about this but the characters also sound boring, it's like the VA's didn't even care at all. Well I can relate to them, who TF will even care voicing for an anime butchered like this? It won't even sell anyway.\n\n
The art is another downfall for this anime. Very bad. I can accept the background art, but it only stopped at that point. It didn't made me go full awe, it's just average. The animation, especially the battle animation, if not with the help of the music, will be pretty freakin' boring. It seems like novices animated them. \n\n
Now going to the good part of the series. The music. No complaints at all. Definitely no. It's just that good. I like every soundtrack I listened in the anime, well maybe because other than that there's absolutely nothing to care about. The dub-step music is good. Every piece of music fits the series well. Highly suggest you to at least listen to it. The OP and ED theme sang by professional artists are both very good, but both the OP and ED sequence are just average. Guess this is the part they waste their money on...I am crying for the wasted potential of the series. \n\n
Another good point of this series is it's world building. It's interesting and unique. Too bad the creators decided not to give a damn shit in building up the world. Sad case man. I like the Sci-fi aspect of the show and I really really hope they can dive deeper into that. \n\n
Well, in conclusion, I freakin' hate this anime, but I'll see it till the end just for the Pros I said just now, but I won't put too much hope into it. \n\n
Thanks for reading.

Beatless tries to do a lot of different things and fails on most of them.
THE GOOD:
Art style is pretty, Lacia the robot heroine is cute and has an interesting multi-layered personality (not 'just a tsundere' or 'just a kuudere' or 'just a genki type' girl). Yuka, MC's sister is fun too and brings some laughs.
THE BAD:
Most of everything else. The anime is basically a story about "can robots love?" "Can AI be considered 'real' ?" "Can robots have souls?". However it also tries to veer into political commentary, this meanwhile trying to make us like the main characters and while all this is happening developinga romantic relationship between the MC and a robot girl that gets thrown on his lap.


I think there have been multiple media pieces about the theme of "can robots love? Is it true love or just a program?" before. There are definitely many different anime shows about this theme as well, check Chobits for example.


My point is this series tries to do too much and doesn't manage to really land anything it tries as a result. I think this series was originally a light novel that is being adapted into anime form. As a result the anime is a rushed mess to display the characters and convince people to buy the books to see the better story.


In short there is a lot to dislike and not enough to keep me hooked. Also disappointed they're already giving us a recap episode after merely 5 (five!) episodes. This hints at production issues.


The plot is also all over the place. It's not hard to understand, it's inconsistent with horrible pacing, and it really shows after the first 3 episodes.


THE CONCLUSION - TL DR:


There is better stuff out there about the same themes Beatless tries to explore, key word being try. But if you're really starved for some new show Beatless probably is interesting on it's own to hold your attention, just don't go in expecting much. What is good and works won't be done enough to warrant a recommendation, and what doesn't work will undoubtedly stand out by the end of your viewing experience.

This anime is like a debate trying to prove the earth is flat, except with robot rights. It's a pointless debate but, sometimes it can sound convincing with the right circumstances. However, Beatless does not do any convincing. The characters are sooo bland and idiotic that they make any semblance of an argument invalid. The political figures and politics are so laughable as they make no logical sense. This leads to an uninteresting world and makes it hard to watch. On the other hand, Beatless has a solid ost with decent artwork which makes it watchable, but is unable to carry its terrible script andcharacters.  


Overall, this anime tries to be somewhat serious but falls on its face hard. The comedy also is pretty cringeworthy and doesn't accomplish much. Characters constantly make bad decisions to push a illogical narrative and motivations are unclear from the start. 


4/10

Beatless is not about robo bitches (or mechanical waifus) but about Brainless studio, writers and artists.
If you love tasteless fan service with lame characters and unbearable plot, this crap is for you.
But I won't give a 0/10 but instead aq 5/10 because this anime helped me learn a lot:
1-Even the guy that directed the first FMA can make absolute CRAP
2-Diomedea is CANCER
3-An anime can be dropped when the plot gets interesting (because it is plain retard)
But it was not meant to be bad. Even if not original, and even if the execution failed miserably, the story is compelling, should have been at least enjoyable, butit was not.\n\n
What went wrong? Lazy 2nd key and in between animation, a lot of argument mistakes of continuity and plot writing, very poor script and very lame characters.\n\n
I think, this could have been a very good seasonal ecchi anime, but even if it does not take itself seriously, you can make a very decent job with at least very smart writing.\n\n
For example, take Sora no Otoshimono. Is not a "good" anime, it does not take itself seriously (except when battle wise as this should have been), but is very enjoyable, is funny and characters even if cliche are very nice. In this, Beatless failed miserably. Bad Sci-fi, terrible argument and not even enjoyable characters.

Overall: 6
This anime falls solidly under the category of "good but not that good." Its best attribute was its conceptual basis: the battle between both AI and humans with different ideas for their future. However the execution was pretty lackluster, with terrible pacing at times and a number of scenes that just fell flat. 
Story: 7
The concepts here aren't new or unique in any way; Chobits explored the issue of human-AI relationships over a decade and a half ago, and more recently a similar conflict was explored in Detroit: Become Human. However, Beatless combines this human-robot identity crisis with political and social issues to spina much more complex and nuanced web of clashing ideals. Instead of the usual dichotomous pro- and anti-bot factions duking it out, we get seven different AI's and at least seven more human factions engaged in both direct and indirect conflict. And while I do have some complaints about the execution, Beatless did a pretty good job of not being too confusing. Also, Arato's philosophy was refreshingly straightforward and a bit different from anything else I've seen in fiction. 

My biggest complaint about the pacing is probably with regards to the relationship between Lacia and Arato. At some points, especially near the beginning and the end, new developments came in rapid-fire, while at other times it felt like it was becoming stagnant. The pacing was also pretty bad in terms of the appearances of Arato's two best buds, to the point where I lost track of who was who because I honestly just forgot that one of them existed by the time he showed up again.


Art: 6

There wasn't much special about the animation. I gave it a point above average because it had less noticeably bad CGI than most, and the use of colors and physical traits to make the different AIs very distinct was pretty good.


Sound: 5

An average soundtrack to me is one where you don't really remember anything about it, except for just a small number of times where it sounded a bit off from what was going off.


Character: 7

In order to keep track of 14+ different humans and AI with different ideals, the characters must be fairly well done so it's easy to distinguish between them and keep track of who's who. Beatless did a pretty good job with this. I also particularly liked Arato's character because of his unique stance on hIE's, which I can totally get behind. However, some of the supporting cast seemed pretty meaningless and superficial, especially Arato's and Kengo's sisters. 


Enjoyment: 6

I found the anime just good enough to want to keep watching, but I never really got hooked. The first two episodes almost did, but just knowing that I'd have to sit through another 16 episodes to get anywhere was pretty off-putting.

Well. What did I just watch.
Beatless is an anime that tries to do so much more, but just... can't. It's a mix and match of so many different other anime, takes the bad things from them at puts them. Its similarity with the infamous Guilty Crown is uncanny.. yet it is so much worse. It takes the bad plot from that anime, mashes it together with poorly developed characters that don't even make any sense. The HIEs seem to be a combination of the Giftias from Plastic Memories, and the androids from Chobits - yet it doesn't quite get anywhere close to the character developmentin either.


Story - 2

The plot is amazingly shallow. I don't even know how it got here. It makes absolutely zero sense. If you don't believe me, spend 20 minutes watching the first episode and you'll understand. This leads directly onto the next category:


Character - 2

The characters in this series are so disappointing. I went into this show thinking it would be mediocre, but the characters are so much worse than your average anime. The MC is just soo naive, his friends have really weird backgrounds - and there's almost no character development.


Sound - 4

Sound is decent in the series. The music is mediocre, and doesn't redeem the series in any way, much unlike other similar shows.


Art - 6

Seems to be the only fair quality in the show. I guess they intended to invest in a bit of fanservice to appeal to the audience, hiding their complete lack of plot and character.


Well that pretty much sums up Beatless. An anime that tries to be more but simply doesn't get anywhere close.

Best way to explain this: So much wasted potential. 
short vers: decent music and art but uninteresting characters with unknown/unclear motivations (I'm not sure if some of them have any idea of what they actually want to do), plot wanders randomly around, incorporating totally random elements (fashion show? and the zombie robot mini apocalypse thing was even more wtf).  To make it worse there is a lot of filler and 3 recap episodes 17 episodes in. I know the recaps are technically beatless intermission but still...
More "in depth:"
With the premise there is so many things they could have explored, especially since our current worldseems to be moving in this direction regarding ai development. I mean just a few days ago google showed off a new ai that can mimic human speech. It wouldn't be far fetched in the future to create an ai that can almost flawlessly imitate a human. If it walks, talks, and looks like a human, is it one? Should it be treated as one? At what point, if any, can you acknowledge an AI as an equal and not some kind of tool? Just watch as an "AI rights" group pops up.

The topic of an "analog hack" brought up is actually a fascinating topic that unfortunately hasn't been explored very deeply. If it something appears close enough to be human, it will force people to unconsciously acknowledge them as such, and thus you can physically "hack" humans through machines. And if the machines are made to aware of this they could also exploit it. Why would the machines need to rise up all terminator style when they could just manipulate us into putting them into positions of power where they could exterminate us whenever they wanted? So many places/directions this could go.


And it goes no where. They could have easily cut the episode count in half(maybe even by 2/3) and overall the plot would still be the same. And it is random enough that it is actually really hard to spoil. I'd have to write a large paragraph. And I doubt you'd care if I'd spoiled everything. Not like it would impact your enjoyment that much. Unfortunately this is not a slice of life anime so this is a really bad thing. To those thought provoking questions above it has pretty much provided "yes" and "no" answers from different characters in a repetitive fashion that have little to no backing/explanations/reasoning. It is shallow, skin deep. It is like watching an argument consisting solely of a repeat of "AI are tools" "No they are not""They are tools""they are not they have feelings" over and over and over again. This argument sometimes turns violent but...


The action/animation/sound is decent I guess. Doesn't stand out in a bad way or a good one. So unfortunately not much eye/ear candy either. 


The characters, well they are nothing special, the generic type where you'd prob forgot their names right after finishing the show, and maybe even while the show is airing. I don't hate them I don't like them, they are just there. The fact that I don't even know what else to put here should be pretty telling in of itself......


Beatless touches upon profound topics but only skims the surface. And it skims it the same way repeatedly time and time again it starts to get boring. And most of the show is aimless, directionless filler that isn't funny or serious/engaging. It's like stalking your neighbor. Unless he's a really interesting person that going to get boring real fast. 

Overall a 6 from me, which is rather bad as I tend to rate rather high (though I'm sort of stingy on 10s). Pretty much the score I give a show that doesn't quite manage to bore me to death but is almost there.

There is a great deal about this anime that I like.  Really compelling ideas are both thrust into the viewer face, and with a little thought there are ideas lurking beneath the surface of what is seen.  I know that is very vague, but it's the great ideas this anime plays with that entertains me the most.
Basically this anime focuses on the relationship between an android (called hIE's) and a high school adolescent.  There are a wide variety of events the two go through, which is pretty well foreshadowed by their initial meeting.  One can expect excitement to find the pairbecause of their importance to many outside forces.


The female lead (hIE) Lacia is (surprise!) a very special android with advanced capabilities.  Arato, the male lead is (surprise!) a strait forward nice guy who can come through in the clutch.  These characters are not original in any shape or form, but their roles work well within the larger context of the story.


And this is why this anime will be enjoyable for some.  There is a lot of play with artificial intelligence, robotics, social engineering, brainwashing, software protocols and potential future changes that can effect the entire landscape of reality.  So even though this anime may appear cliche, trope, whatever - it actually isn't if you follow all the dialog and the potential implications.


However, I'd be the first to admit, I am completely forgiving some blatantly bad elements of this anime.  Namely frequent flash back moments, complete episode recaps, and diversions from the overall arc.  Also, in spite of all the fun had with smart ideas - their is a great deal of potential squandered.  Stakes could be higher, characters more complex/developed, clearer motivations, and more consistency from episode to episode.  There really are strong and weak episodes.  There is a lot of discussion right now about FB and social media, and how peoples minds are being steered or even altered as a result of media interaction.  This is an idea Beatless hints at, but doesn't really fully take advantage of.  I mention this, because I feel this way about a lot of the ideas presented - unrealized potential.


I'm a big fan of the opening.  There's solid artistic detail, the music is excellent, and a lot can be learned about the anime just by watching it - in other words, it's what I want as an anime fan.  In almost exact contrast, the credits exemplify some of the worst parts of the anime.  Don't get me wrong, still good music, and it's well made - but for me a montage about the main character's sister's daily life has no relevance.


Probably not an anime just anyone can really like - but if some of the core elements sound appealing (androids, AI, relationships between machines and people, social engineering) - might be worth a look.  Overall a 7/10 for me so far

Beatless is supposed to be about love between humans and machines. After 10 episodes, though, I wouldn't be able to tell you what this show is actually about. It lacks logic, coherency, a consequential PLOT. This anime is just action scenes piled on fan service and long, tedious dialogues about technology. Here's the tea.

As I said above, the story isn't really there. I can't tell if the plotis about the relationship between Lacia and Male Main Character, or men vs technology, or h-IEs dynamics. I didn't understand sh*t.

Lacia is very beautiful, and so are her sisters. That's it. That's what saves this anime: pretty girls.


Sound: 9

Perhaps the only good this about this anime is the soundtrack. I enjoyed it a lot, even if it gets a bit too much sometimes. The opening is very good.


Character: 5

They have the depth of a teaspoon. That's all.


Enjoyment: 2

I suffered through 9 episodes out of 10. The first one promises so much, but then one goes on watching and everything just kind of... falls apart, I guess.

Story-5

Art-7

Sound-8

Character-6

Enjoyment-5

Overall-5 (yeah 5 don't add up, maybe 6, but it's a 5)

Havent seen the original material (LN/Manga), so you can cut me some slack.
Lets start with the good points.
Art - 6:
Its not really bad to be honest, it has some low quality productions, where you can see lots of still frames, or recycled ones, but overall its fair. The opening is where it shines the most, and some fight scenes.
Sound - 6:
It has decent sound tracks across the series, especially on few notable moments, during fights or in the last episode. Opening track is good, ending is good (although, not on my tastes). Have heard lots of recycled sounds though. Voice acting seems good enough tonot annoy at least.


From here on, its only downhill.


Story - 4:


The idea is good on paper. I mean, humanity has advanced enough, to develop AI. The AIs are tasked with the development on humanity. Until they hit a wall, because after some certain accident, the humans became cautious of the AIs (looking at you, Skynet). 


So, some years later, the accident is already in history books. A certain person from a certain organization, decides, humanity progress is bad, and they cant really do anything by themselves anymore. He orchestrates some stuff, in which, he lets some hIEs (human-like robots), on the loose. 


They are really powerful, with different abilities. One of them is as well super-AI. They are tasked with different missions, all for the "good" of humanity (good, as in depending on point of view).


Aaaand then it meets the production of the anime.


The anime has aired 28 episodes. Can you guess, how many recaps are there, for those 2 and half seasons? 


If your answer was between 0 and 2, well.... you are in for a big surprise. They are so many, that i lost count of them. I think they sit around 4, 5 or 6. 

Yes, thats right! About 20-25% of the aired episodes, were recaps!


The pacing is really bad. 


The story telling is jagged at some points, and the story progression is often forced, with lack of logic at certain moments - Character A, meets by accident Character B, which turns out to be also an owner of one of those super hIE robots, that are on the loose. Coincidentally, their mutual friend, Character C, ALSO is an owner of one of those.


Then, Character D, transfers into their school (who could have known, all of the people are high schoolers), and ALSO owns such a hIE robot. 


Cliche-valanche.


Character - 2:


I havent seen so badly written and animated characters in a while.


Arato, the MC, is a wanna-be whimpy kid. Bullied kids today have more balls than him.

Then, we have one of his friends, an edgy wanna-be. A little more ballsy than him, but still a whimpy baby.

The 3rd friend, in that group, is a son of one of the most powerful hIE companies, who is knowledgable about stuff left and right. The brainiac of the group, and supposedly the most mature one in terms of mentality.


Everything else is to be considered as side characters (as humans i mean). 


Lacia, is a robot, which is the 2nd MC, super-AI, which is a kinda of the "EVERYTHING IS GOING ACCORDING TO MY PLAN" cliche. 


Not kinda, its like that actually.


Lots can be said about characters, character development, character design and such.


Most of it will be negative. If the story pacing wasn't bad enough to make you drop this from watching it, the characters will do it.


Enjoyment - 2: 


With the above 2 poor marks, i don't see how i can enjoy this. If you read the reddit discussions, TONS of people dropped it even before the half of the first season (around ep 5-6-7).


Overall - 3:


The art and sound are the main saving grace to not give it 2 or 1.


If you are a masochist, who likes whiny, dumb, teenage main characters, who believe that friendship and love will save the world, then this is the right anime for you!


Otherwise, just do not bother.

When I heard there was a show that was described as a "Spiritual Successor" to Guilty crown, by the same creators,  I was overwhelmed with hype. 
Across message boards, and even on MAL, the excitement for anything close to GC was palpable- especially since we knew we'd never get another season, since that series, unlike most modern anime, actually had a definitive end.
So, how did a show that was setup for success from the jump- with the same creators, a HIGHLY similar plot, and with a nearly identical emotional and aesthetic pallet- fail at recapturing or surpassing the expectations of their creators' previously belovedworks?


Well, for one, they just didn't change enough, and sometimes that makes a new work essentially a caricature of a previous one. This is a dilemma that plagues all artists and art forms- when an artist gets great reception, and their fans keep demanding more of the same, the artist may focus to closely on their previous work and end up making a lesser version of it- a sophomore slump, if you will. 


This is one of those slumps to a large degree. What we have here is essentially a budget re-skin of Guilty Crown. I'm honestly not sure if it falls short from expectations because of a lack of effort, a lack of self-awareness, or both. 


The best comparative example of how Beatless rates next to its predecessor Guilty Crown is that of "Brynhildr of Darkness" to "Elfen Lied". Elfen Lied was a cult classic that is still referenced today as one of the greatest gore anime of all time, while Brynhildr is seen as the "spiritual Successor" that will rarely be remembered- not because its necessarily "bad", but because its basically a caricature of its predecessor. 


The worst offenses in describing what this anime does worse than its predecessor, and many of its contemporaries, can be described in 2 parts:


1. It's plot is incredibly slow moving in its first half, and feels disjointed and directionless about 70% of the time. Its latter half is actually much better in its pacing, but sadly, that's when many of the loose ends don't get to see a proper conclusion. 


2. It spends an inordinate amount of time on fan service, but, whats worse is that most of the fan-service filler is essentially pandering to the "sister-lover" pseudo incestual anime tropes that seems to be so popular these days. Oh, do I loathe sister-lovers. 


To showcase how little the writers deviated from their previous works when they came up with the plot for Beatless, and to give a quick example of what I meant by this show being a shameless "Re-skin of Guilty Crown", here are the two shows Synopses, edited slightly in order to showcase the similarities:


Here is an excerpt from Mal's "Beatless" Synopsis: 

      "....kind-hearted high school student Arato Endou..is viciously assaulted by a hacked hIe ( human-like robot)...he is saved by Lacia, a highly advanced hIEs that recently escaped the clutches of the mysterious MemeFrame Corporation... in exchange for saving his life, he must register as her new owner, thus taking full responsibility for her actions..." 


Now here is an excerpt from Mal's "Guilty Crown" Synposis: 

     "...weak and unsociable Shuu Ouma (is attacked) during a crucial operation, which results in him (being saved by) Inori Yuzuriha, a member of a guerrilla group called Funeral Parlor, (who is escaping the clutches of a mysterious military corporation called GHQ). He (is then forced into) obtaining the "Power of Kings".... Now an unwilling participant in the struggle against GHQ, Shuu must learn to control his newfound power...(and take full responsibility of the actions of Inori and Funeral Parlor)"


Beside the lack of creativity in the main plot, The differences that account for such a drastic difference in enjoyment and quality are as such: 


The art and animations are markedly more low budget than most anime of the current season, but even worse is the fact that they seemingly have barely evolved aesthetically from GC over 6 years ago. 


The most glaring issue are the cliches that cage a good premise from being great. Like I previously mentioned, there are lazy, sometimes inappropriately incest-related tropes, and these are not made any better by the thickness of the stories plot armor, logical holes, and the "Deus ex machina"sprinkled throughout it. 


I could forgive Guilty Crowns' faults due to its ambition and the studios obvious love for their anime; sadly, I cannot give Beatless the same level of forgiveness, simply because it truly pales in comparison in its originality, writing, animation and overall quality. 


On a funnier note, Beatless still completely outclasses many modern anime, including the horrifyingly terrible "Clockwork Planet", which so obviously stole from Beatless that its cringe inducing. 


EVERYTHING ASIDE, this isn't a horrible anime. It's problems stem from the same place that many well-meaning anime series do- it's simply confused as to what exactly it wants to be. They knew that they had to please fans by making Beatless a "spiritual successor", rather than its own unique series. They also knew they had to modernize this new series- which meant injecting enough "moe", "sister-love" and fan-service for the newer generation of otaku's. Look, I get it. The industry is a business, and that's what is selling, sadly. Anime has seen a steady decline in its quality of writing in the past 10 years due to the fickle nature of the industry and the obsession with creating the next great marketable franchise, and we all suffer for it. 


Thankfully, the show has enough mystery, intrigue and fan-service to keep its viewers' attention for long enough for them to get through this relatively short series and formulate their own opinion of it. 


In the end, a score of 6 is fairly generous, and, to be honest, a partially courteous gesture due to this anime being the next best thing for a dead franchise with no hopes of return. 


Despite my largely negative review, I would still suggest this to fans of Guilty Crown, Brynhildr in the Darkness, Elfen Lied and dare I say it, SOA.

The Heroine: Is a mixed bag. drawn to be extremely attractive(success IMO) however the premise she keeps stating is she has no emotions and yet seems to convey them over and over again if nothing else via body language. The story that Beatless is trying to tell is AWESOME. Unfortunately, they keep stumbling over their feet, staggering from episode to episode.
What they are TRYING to do is explore in a serious fashion the role of AI in our society: Will AI fully integrate and dwell along side us us? Will it be malevolent and try to replace people? Or will people feel threatened and put limits on the AI?
The action takes place in a world where human looking androids are common, but almost all are linked to central AI that assists them in dealing with the incredibly complex creatures known as humans (So theyare not truly independent)


The only exception are 5 rogue androids that have a much more advanced AI, and are fully autonomous. These androids (called Hie) are surrogates for the various points of view (on human -AI interaction) that Beatless proposes 


The problem is the male lead character, who bonds with the android representing coexistence is so bland that he sets your teeth on edge. And the whole modeling plot makes no sense. But that is a recurring problem with the show: too many b-plots that don't go anywhere or add to the the story.


That is partly because the characters represent points of view, so they often behave in a nonsensical manner, and you are left scratching your head to their motivations.


All in all, this show could have been really good, but as it is , you have to squint to see the good parts amongst all the chaff.

Themes in a story are usually best when they're simple.  A clear-cut message delivered to the audience does much better because this way, there's little reason for the quality of the story to be sacrificed in exchange for more complicated hullabaloo that for some reasons, some people believe is 'good writing'.  All of that ironically comes in the form of the one word title of 'Beatless', where more than just a few 'beats' are missing when it comes to this one.
Story:
Beatless takes place in a version of the future where artificial intelligence units known as hIe's have become commonplace in society, working smaller jobs andmore dangerous jobs, slowly encroaching their foothold in the world as everything becomes more and more automated.  It's here where our main protagonist, Arato Endo, comes in contact with Lacia, an hIe who is one of five special units that've escaped a special facility, and becomes her owner to help pave the way for humanity's future.


On the surface, Beatless is a show that touches upon the themes of AI usage as the world of Beatless grows ever more reliant on automated computers and the future of humanity as a whole, as different perspectives of how humanity should approach the first point come into play.  But given the complexity of that sentence and the kinds of insinuation that could come from said sentence, what we end up getting is perhaps one of the most poorly structured shows in the history of the anime medium.


While the first episode seems to give the audience some semblance of what the show should be about, what ends up happening is the show adding on layers upon layers of various terms, situations, characters, organizations, and events that muddy what could've been a compelling piece on our society's growing reliance on technology, into something that's basically incomprehensible to your average viewer as as characters stand or sit around for ten or so minutes at a time info-dumping their debates with walls of text that for the most part have almost no relevance as to what's going on because it's all junk that doesn't really matter at the end.


This problem is catalyzed further from how the show jumps around from event to event, creating a numerous amount of unsolved plot threads that have you scratching your head at the characters' motivations, as well as unsolved plot points that after a given episode, will drop you into something else entirely in the next cause who needs closure to a confrontation when we should instead be focusing on what the imouto has been up to these past few episodes while tensions run high between differing points of view?  That won't be jarring to the audience at all!


So many problems arise from situations like these, and this is one of the few cases where you expect the show to get worse and worse because by barely the halfway point, the show establishes that it basically can't tell a proper story.  Hell, Diomedia KNEW that this show was overtly complicated, so much so that they have four recap episodes in between arcs to 'refresh' the audience on what just happened.  You know you screwed up when you have to recap four times, and even with that, things STILL don't make much sense.  What's worse is that the show isn't even over.  There's a mini second season in the works to cap off the story, and the supposed finale doesn't really do anything to even build tension cause the shit just ends without a second thought.


Overview:

+ Interesting premise

-  WAY too complicated

-  Four recap episodes (Like seriously?  Four?!)

-  Horrendous pacing

-  How in blazes is two cours not enough for this story?


Characters:


Endo Arato is a useless character.  Described as a sympathetic 'nice guy' who treats the android hIe's like people, Arato for the majority ninety five percent of the series is just a figurehead for the show where things just happen around him.  To his credit, it makes sense sort of why he is the show's figurehead, but the guy does almost nothing to impact that plot, so little that you could make Lacia's owner a cardboard cutout and no one would be able to tell the difference.  This is because most of the series happens behind our protagonist's back, and he's more or less strung along for the ride that, while the show acknowledges it, still doesn't do him any favors cause he doesn't really develop, more so that just exist and change when see fit.  He's not a character, and he actually feels more fake than the fake android waifu that he has accompanying him for the majority of the series.


Then there's Lacia, the actual protagonist that does something, but is never shown because why would we as the audience need to see ANYTHING happen when we can just be told that it happened?  As one of the five Lacia-class hIe's, Lacia spends the majority of the show stringing along her owner to do shit according to her whims (even though he's supposed to be the owner), ultimately making a reveal towards the end of the series that surprises no one considering how little the MC actually contributes to the series and how much Lacia has to pull up the slack in order to create some kind of interest for what's happening.  There are moments of her character in the beginning that do create the interesting dynamic of what her place as an android is in this world since Arato treats her like a human despite her being a tool for humanity, but there're so few and so close to the beginning that it's pretty negligible in the long run.


And of course, there's nothing else to note when it comes to the rest of this cast.  Despite the main duo being far less that exemplary characters, they are by comparison so much better than everyone else that almost no one else is worth mentioning.  True the show attempts to create different versions of what the ideal human society should be with the four other Lacia-class units and respective owners, but their reasoning and motivation for even pursuing the future that they want is so baseless that Arato somehow has the most solid foundation of the four 'owners' in the series.  Not only that, but the show throws in so many different organizations with differing directions on how to handle the series's different situations that by the time you get understanding as to what everyone wants, you'll see that so many things lack reason that it's no wonder why the story flopped so hard.  (Sure it could be a commentary on how people have differing opinions, but why do that here, damnit?)


Overview:

+ Lacia is at least somewhat interesting

- Too many perspectives

- MC is largely uninteresting


Art:


Diomedia's efforts to make Beatless look good was largely successful.  At least color-wise.  Closeups used in the show do have a nice and detailed sheen to them, but for the most part, if you're looking at the actual art and animation, there's nothing much to write home about.


However I will give the show due credit with its background, as many of the farther shots, especially mixed in with the bright color scheme do aid in making the show look a lot better than it otherwise should've.  Diomedia's not a top contender for having overly pretty art, so seeing some nice quality stuff from them is a nice treat, even if the show itself suffers from poor story elements.


Sound:


Personally, I find anything other than GARNiDELiA's 'Error' to be subpar at best.  This isn't really a gripe with any of the other songs, but it's just that Error stands out so much more than its partner ED and the second pair of OP and ED that I really can't make a fair analysis by comparison.  I put this more on my bias with Error since it has such a catchy and unique beat to it whereas everything else sounds very samey despite them all being made by different artists.  Which is a shame since they're good, but just not AS good.


Personal Enjoyment:


I've realized that I write one of four kinds of reviews.  There're ones where I praise every aspect of the show, ones about shows that I like but point out flaws, those about shows I don't like but give the benefit of the doubt, then finally the ones where I sit down and sit down and systematically explain why almost every aspect of the show sucks and ask myself "Why did I watch this?" and "Why was this made?"  Those are the most fun to write because after months of finding myself realizing that I made a wrong choice, I get vindication by writing something that absolutely guts every aspect of a show's being because it's amazing how something this bad could ever be put on TV or shown to the public.


I honestly have not gotten this mad at a show since Sousei no Omnyouji, and that was more than a year ago; every fiber of my being was yelling at the screen over how little sense everything in Beatless made.  There were times when each episode felt like nothing was achieved, and those that seemed like things was progression had little to no explanation as to why things happened, creating a vicious cycle of never-ending bad storytelling that only got worse with time.  Hell an android basically livestreamed herself commit property damage and commit suicide without any real context as to why any of that happened.  The hell am I supposed to get from that?


As a result of this, I got no enjoyment from watching this series, agonizing through the walls of texts and debates over AI, humans, and what humanity is supposed to be, which is all a real shame considering I actually had hopes for the series once upon a time, and the beginning was enough to keep my interest for the show until it decided that the plot could only move through the use of the little sister's random impulses, and any kind of cohesive theme was thrown out the window for complex plot threads that get largely unfinished and are extremely unsatisfactory to watch.  If you ask me, this is a show worth skipping.  It's a show that tries to be about everything but ends up being about nothing, giving it no positive merit aside from wasted time because quite honestly, things just happen, and that is not good writing.


That aside, "Error" is one of my favorite OPs, which is ironic considering it comes from a show I despise.

Jesus Christ this was a trash fire. Beatless is about the journey of a high school aged boy named Arato. Arato’s world takes place in the far future, where hyper realistic robots are common and prevalent. These robots are called hIE’s, and they’ve integrated themselves into normal life as servants. Arato treats these hIE’s as equals, falling in love with them at times. One night, Arato encounters an odd looking, powerful, hyper intelligent AI hIE holding a coffin that saves him from a car hacked to target humans. In exchange for saving him the hIE asks him to become her owner. As her owner, Aratois responsible for everything that she does. Therefore, he has to deal with those related to and enemy of his new hIE, named Lacia.

	Now, that synopsis doesn’t sound that bad, but trust me when I say the show is much much worse. Female robots are nothing new, and a show based around them isn’t either. But me personally has had a bad experience with them, first with Chobits, which I found descent, second being the more recent Clockwork Planet, which was a complete shitshow. Looking through the Winter anime season, this anime is 26 episodes, I thought to give this type of robot girl show another chance. And with watching this show once a week for 6 months, it has ruined the genre for me.

	So the main issue about Beatless is that it doesn’t make sense. The show has so many conflicting plot points that: 1. Just don’t work, and 2. Makes it so nothing is resolved, 3. It doesn’t even matter in the long run. In fact, there are so many things that don’t matter that they have to make not 1, not 2, not 3, but 4 recap episodes. And I doubt that was done due to a confusing storyline. Because from a look of the show, they didn’t have a lot of budget to work on. Art and animation is severely underwhelming, along with a soundtrack that is only decent at best. Every single character is one dimensional, retarded, and make complete one eighties at random moments as the barely coherent demands. 

         Arato is the worse case here. He falls in love with Lacia, his robot, who has specified that she doesn’t have feelings. Yet, he goes to great lengths to protect her, even putting real human lives in danger. Although, the worst thing about this relationship they have forged, is that the show doesn’t depict this show as a good thing at all. It doesn’t give their relationship any good points. Beatless just shows them being together, nothing spectacular, but the length Arato goes to keep their relationship isn’t worth it. The conflict in the show doesn’t even come from their relationship, but only as a catalyst for more trouble to occur. The main troubles of the show come from those who are after Lacia, which include the government, a secret organization against hIE’s, and Lacia’s other models or “sisters”. Lacia’s sisters are a major part of the show, 5 of them including Lacia, and they all represent a different part of human progress. Weapons, evolution, etc. And the end point of the show is that they all try and make a different future, according to what their owner wants. This by far is the most interesting thing about the show, to bad it's covered by bad, well, everything.

        This show has no redeeming factors. I cannot recommend this to anyone whether you like this type of show or not. I give this show a 1 out of 10. This has been PixEFit’s spoiler free, but not really review on Beatless.

This is a series with a reasonable amount of action and a protagonist that doesn't have me grinding my teeth wishing for a fraction of backbone. It needs to be said that ep 6 is a recap. The story up to that point is somewhat fun and active, but a recap before a ep 11 or 12 is worse than a week without in my opinion. I may change this as the anime progresses, but damagehas been done and I'm left expecting a recap at every quarter.

I have to say before going into this review that I did stick it out to the hiatus that goes until September of this year, and still intend to continue watching then because I need to feel like I gave this anime a chance to repent for all of my wasted time. I had initally intended to drop this crap after episode one but act a visit back with a few more episodes in, it was able to "lie" me back into watching again until it was too late to stop. Onward!
The best way to describethis anime is with two words. Pathetic disaster!

The story is a complete mess that makes no sense or simply throws plot around without meaning.

I'm also sorry to say this to the people who like the story, but the story creators seem to just not understand even vaguely the existential qualities and mythology of there own story. (apologies to the novel if the it is just poor adaption which is probable.)

The MC is horribly stupid, and other characters are not anything other than plot devices.

The romance is not even a romance and defending it as such rebuts the shows points. (Sorry to the people who may have watched this for that reason.)

The amount of recaps is way, way too much.

The animation is just horrendous as times. (Worst I have ever seen for an anime.)

The anime ends abruptly with a hiatus for several months because of lack of budget.


There is not a single redeeming quality of this anime and I really am quite afraid of how many people gave this anime anything more that a possible 4/10. For those people I can only think they are either completely looking past every single problem or actually don't understand the anime to begin with and just simply want some girls fighting in tight superhero like suits. If I have not said enough yet, please read onward where I break down exactly every single problem with this anime.


From the end of episode one I knew I was going to hate this anime.

The tag line of the anime is "I trust your smile. I don't care whether you are soulless or not." Which this is how the episode ended (not sure if it was first or second episode to be exact). This phrase seems to be some sort of word trickery or just flat out stupidity, because very few people go around day to day thinking of souls and smiles as defining reasons for something being a "person"... Furthermore, anyone who is not religious could really not give a crap anyways about souls, which makes me think and really wonder if the creators just didn't have words like "consciousness" under the belt or it was just a wrong way of treating the translation. To simply hinge all of what is defined in "personhood", by something like "souls" is just plain stupid dualism.

This is honestly the first mistake the whole series ever made, and forgive me, I have never read the novel/manga, but if it dose the same thing (which I think is dose use the same term "soul") then it was also a dualism mistake there too. I could sit here and say all the worlds that needed to be used like phenomenal consciousness, functional consciousness, qualia, functionalism vs. dualism, the philosophical zombie argument, the Chinese Room argument, but just explaining away these terms probably wouldn't help you see my point and I think I have made it clear enough already anyways the fact that the story that this anime presented has none of these terms or ideas ever implemented. It's like they really didn't care if they were accurate, like with the word "soul" instead of anything else which was more reasonable.


The rest of the story after the first episode is a long road that just goes nowhere really. The whole series has very little of anything actually meaningful going on, and as each episode went by, I thought to myself at the end, "Well we still have not really got anywhere have we?" (Along with "I sure hope the next is not another recap.") By the end of the last few episodes before the hiatus things finally feel like they are moving however still at a sluggish rate, without any actual questions answered which should have been far, far earlier answered.

You see I wouldn't have made such a big deal about the whole "soul" thing either normally, except it's really a good example of lack of really any sense that the story has just simply from square one, and the animation and all execution following as a complete trainwreck makes good examples of a poor amount of effort put in in general, along with complete lack of budget. Which is what I think is what a lot of this anime suffered from most. But even if the story writers had done there homework and been more careful with what words, or themes, or ideas they used, executed plot properly, the rest of the dicey animation quality, and the recaps would still have existed because of lack of budget.


As for characters, the MC, he is the single most annoying one from any anime that has every existed and he is total and utter crap because he never has a free will of his own. By the time he starts making decisions for himself (very close to the beginning of hiatus until September), it feels like the anime is almost over and it just feels like it's something that should have happened far earlier in the show. The entire rest of the characters are either fan service by having sexy girls fight and or, are simply plot devices to plot that makes no real head way anywhere anyways. The fan service is really troubling at times with the characters and although there is not nudity, it still feels like every single plot point is to make more girls fight in sexy cloths. I really feel like the creators just didn't give a crap anymore about the story or anything else and just wanted use this as a step by step to get more fan service in. That's really sad...


This is a real kicker for people but the romance is not even a real romance and it's so easy to see that it's an illusion and the MC is just a dumb cuck. That's what really has to be said. I have been waiting for some evidence the entire time that the romance may be real because I really, really don't want it to be, but it is just fake. They talk about these "analogue hacks" and what is sad is that some people who watch either don't realize it (or don't want to realize it) that THAT IS NOT THE SAME AS THE REAL THING. Which it is a CONFIRMED imitation by the hIEs themselves. It's like someone telling you "I don't really love you, I'm just using you.", they are just acting the part of the romance, then you believe that they still love you.

An AI that imitates is just an imitation. It's fake. That doesn't mean that the hIEs should not be taken seriously, on the contrary it takes the MC the entire first part of the season to realize this before he blurts it out. Pathetic.

Honestly I have been wishing the entire time that somehow some real romance happens, and I have at least a spec of solid evidence that it's real. This is honestly the only way I can see this anime being even partially redeemed for wasting my time. 


Maybe this is the only thing this anime actually dose ok. The "hope" for a romance (or that this anime gets better in some way) that pretty much every ones wanted since episode one, and is what the MC always wanted. This, my last ditch effort for hope. Some people have said that that's the point of the anime... I can't really see that as the point. There are too many things at play for it to all boil down to just simple metaphors for problems with romance and the possible lies of love. Still, this is the only bit of fan service I will give into because it would fundamentally change the entire message of the story. I don't like the way they pose the hIEs as emotionless tools. But that's what they truly are. A single act of proving this wrong however would be enough.

I really, really, really, want to see Lacia come out and show proof of her emotions, but every time it's possible it's just proven to be a lie. I feel like now this is the only thing tying people to hanging on to this anime for so long, they so too want this to happen but no matter their hopes, every time it betrays them.
